title: Qidi Tech 1 Raspberry Pi Camera Bed Mount

description.text:
I was tired of not having a nice spot to put my Raspberry Pi Camera, and I decided to try to bed mount it. I first created the camera mount, which locks to the bed arm (very snuggly). I decided to use the gopro system as I had a few extra arms around from my gopro. Then I found a raspberry Pi Camera case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1528783) that utlized an arm.

However, possibly due to the fact that I have an off brand pi camera, mine wouldn't fit. Plus I was having issues with the screws and screw holes, so figured I would build my own holder that would fit snuggly into the arm and hold my camera without any screws.

Do note - the pins on the camera body holder file, aren't perfect when you put your camera in. This was intentional and meant to provide tension to hold the camera in place. You will have to work it into place and it won't just "push on" easily but it does fit.

After fitting it in, it is tight clearances with the extruder head but it works. I also included a shot of my camera's image that it took so you can see how the image is. The Z steps are no big deal and it is locked firmly. You can see that I have a slight tilt to my image, and that is due to the gopro arms and how I routed them. For just checking on my prints from work, this is fine. But if I made a timelapse I would probably make sure it was level or level the video in post. Also, it is a little blurry, but that's unfortunately due to my focal range on the camera.

author: haplo31

description.text:
Customized with 3D Slash.

I have just modified the structure for a narrower switch and add two small holes for the side screws.

You still need to put a small attachment to the power supply on the other side, I fixed it with some glue :P

I decided that the timing belt gear in my plastruder was just too unreliable, so I wanted to try out a worm gear drive cog like I'd seen others have good success with.  I have a cheap 9x20 lathe and a tap set, but I was missing something to hold the gear blank to the tap while letting it rotate.  So I fabbed one.
This isn't a robust thing, but it's good enough, and I've been able to make several small brass worm gears with it.

Print tool with fairly solid infill.  Dip the fork in acetone for just a second to make sure the layers bind to each other.  Let re-harden overnight.  Carefully ream out hole with 15/64's drill bit.
Prepare a worm gear blank by lathing a brass or steel rod to 0.5 inches outside diameter.  Make a flat bottomed groove right near the end, with angled walls.  Like thus: \_/  Make the bottom of the groove be 0.4 inches diameter.  Try to make the groove fit a 3mm 0.6 pitch tap snugly.  Bore a 15/64 inch (0.235 inch) hole through the center of the end, and part off the piece at 0.45 inch length.  Cool and wash the chip from the part, and de-burr any sharp edges.
Take the plastic extruded holder and fit the part into the fork, and slip a 7/32 or slightly smaller allen wrench, or an appropriate sized bolt through the holes to hold the part in place.  It should be able to rotate freely.  load the 3mm 0.6 pitch tap into the lathe chuck, and mount the extruded part holder into the tool post so that the tap nestles nicely in the groove.  Tighten the tool post screws gently.  You don't need a lot of force.  Just enough to hold it in place snugly.
Set the lathe speed to its slowest speed, hopefully around 200 RPM.  Start the lathe up, and feed the part into the tap slowly.  The part should start rotating on its own as the tap feeds it.  Drip cutting oil onto the tap as it cuts.  Each time the part rotates fully around once, feed it into the tap another 0.005 inches or so.  If you get much resistance to feeding it into the tap, stop and let it go around another time.  TAPS ARE FRAGILE!  They can snap easily.
Once you can see that the bottom of the groove is fully rounded out and is fully threaded, you can stop.
Now, you can take the newly made worm gear over to a drill press to drill a hole in its side, so that you can tap the hole for a set screw.  I used a #10-32 set screw in the picture above.

comments.text: Oh, my - I never would have thought that a printed part would survive on a metalworking tool, but I guess it can.  Time to experiment!
comments.author: bowdidge

comments.text: The trick is that you never really put much of any stress on the tool, other than a light compression from the end.

description.text:
Removed 2017-04-14:
Removed the old versions, now there are files only for the latest version.
I have changed the spec for the threaded rods to 340 and 290 mm.

Added 2017-03-23:
I remade the two endpoints by moving the screws a little bit to the left to make more room for the belt and belt mount. Also made the cylinders where the screws are inserted into less depp for a more easy assembly into the printer. The files have version number "2.1".

Added 2017-02-19:
I have added a lower profile belt tensioner that gives 8mm more Y space in the front, file "Y-axis belt3.stl".
I have also added files for the belt mount under the heat bed, files "Y belt bedmount.stl" and "Y belt bedmount w offset.stl"

The stock design for the Y-axis on a A8 printer is not good. The Y-axis belt is clamped between the front and back of the printer. When the belt is tensioned the front and back will be bent towards each other and the Y Engine mount will rotate slightly. Also when the Y-carriage make direction changes the front and back moves a litte bit in relation to the print head and the frame. This can lead to imperfections on the print.

One solution is to print frame stabilizers to make the front/back more stiff and resilient to bend. However, the principle to have the frame cope with belt tension is wrong.

With this model I'm trying another approach, to decouple the Y-axis belt tension from the frame. The belt, roller, motor is contained in an integrated module. The belt tension is balanced by the two 6mm threaded bars and not by the frame. This module is then only attached to the back frame of the printer.
As a bonus we get a nice belt tensioner for Y.

There are two files for the belt mount under the hot bed. One to use when the hotbed H alu bracket is turned upside down (Y_belt_bedmount_w_offset.stl) and another when the H bracket is mounted with the middle section of the H downwards (Y_belt_bedmount.stl).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

At least 40% and 95% on belt tensioner

Notes:

i Would strongly recommend an infill of 90% with the belt tensioner to get it strong.

You could also print the motor part with the motor mount down on the heated (thanx naifa). the model needs to be placed 0.9mm beneath Z=0 in order to flatten out the motor mount.

Remove structures (obviously).
The 6 mm holes for threaded rods might have to be drilled to dimension.
The four "pins" that is supposed to fit in the four holes of the front may need some sanding to fit.

Bill of materials

1 pc. 6 mm stainless steel threaded rod, 340 mm long.
1 pc. 6 mm stainess steel threaded rod, 290 mm long.
6 pc. 6 mm stainless steel locknut.
6 pc. stainless steel washer for 6 mm screw.
1 pc. 3 mm axle or screw without head, 17 mm long.
1 pc. belt roller for GT2 belt, 16 teeth, 6 mm wide (or original roller)

Assembly

Note that the belt mount under the bed will be removed completely since it is too bulky. You need to make a clamp of 1-2 mm metal with two holes matching the holes where the original belt was. Clamp the belt between the metal clamp and the bed with two screws and a nut.

  • Cut the 6mm threaded bars into two pieces of 340 and 290 mm length
  • Touch up the end on the rods where you cut
  • Assemlbe the rods, the endstops, the belt roller and all nuts and wahsers as in the pictures
  • Remove the Y blank rods by pulling the through the hole in the front
  • Remove the belt mount and remove the bed
  • Remove the stock Y motor mount
  • Insert the assembled unit to its position in the printer as in the pictures
  • Place the bed in place, wrap the belt around the motor axle pulley and put the belt roller in place with the 3mm axle (with the belt around it)
  • Center the 6mm rods between the front and back mounts and turn the back two nuts until they rest against the back mount
  • Tension the belt by moving the belt roller carriage forward and turning the nuts so that they help tensioning the belt to the desired tension
  • Fasten the motor mount in the back frame using the original screw/nut that held the stock motor mount
  • Turn the frontmost two nuts on the rod until they rest against the front mount, do NOT tension so that the front is pressed forward and bends. There is no need for tension here other than to prevent the front mount from being loose
  • If the printer is mounted on a base plate: Fasten the motor mount to the base plate with a screw in the slotted hole on the motor mount
  • You may need to check that the belt is in parallell with the blank bars, I had to move the belt roller on the Y motor axis a couple of mm away from the motor

comments.text:
The idea behind this thing is being an alternative to the frame braces that are just distributing the forces to the outermost threaded rods.
This design takes care of the force needed to keep the belt tensioned and leaves little or no stress in the frame.
I would be very surprised if a combo should improve the prints.

comments.text: The issue seems to be that the Y_belt_bedmount_mount_w_offset.stl hits Y-axis_motor2.stl with or without the nut and washer preventing the Y axis limit switch from being actuated. My solution was to remove the nuts completely from the Y-axis_motor2.stl mount and with an exacto knife cut a very small notch in the left rod mount of Y-axis_motor2.stl so that Y_belt_bedmount_mount_w_offset.stl clears the mount as the bed homes. It doesn't take much and be very careful not to remove too much material.

comments.text: The 290 was a bit short, it worked, but I ended up cutting one at 292mm. 340mm worked for the right side, and left plenty of room for placement and adjustment. comments.text: However, after reading all the different values people have mentioned, I just mounted the fixed end and marked the cut-off point on the other end with some tape.  After cutting it and measuring, my rods were exactly 295mm and 345mm.  So, it's probably best to not cut the threaded rod until you've mounted the printed pieces and measured from the bottom of the cup (aka the face) of the front piece to the bottom of the cups in the rear pieces.  I guess as long as it bottoms out in the back and doesn't slip out of the front you'll be fine.  :)

author: hijamie32

title: Sierpinski pyramide - without the need of support

description.text: This thing design features some Sierpinski pyramides that could be printed without any support structure. In each depth of the pyramide, there are 5 sub-pyramides while the central-upper one is supported by (a non-fractal) upside-down pyramide with the same size. Hence, it can easily be printed and the result will look very nice (see image), and real-world light-shade effects practically "hide" these supporting pyramides. You may able to generate any version for this using the C code attached. See Instructions for further details.

One just has to print the designs without any kind of further tuning or so. First, this design has been printed without any kind of support base (see the file sierpinski_what_is_seen_on_thepic.stl). However, some printer drivers (such as CURA what we are using with UltiMaker) prints the individual smallest triangles on the base individually instead a fully filled square. Therefore, it was very hard to remove the object from the printer after the printout has been completed and smallest pyramides could likely break. Due to this side-effect, the generator program has been modified in order to add a support base with one unit of smallest-pyramide-height. This support can clearly be seen on the attached sierpinski??mm_d?.stl files. Sierpinski pyramide is also a fancy thing to demonstrate STL format: facelets are purely triangles (with the exception of the base) and STL encodes triangles as well. With this design, a C code is shipped (see the *.zip file, with pre-compiled Linux and Windows binaries), with which you can create arbitrary Sierpinski pyramides. And one can teach how recursive algorithms work. See the command line option ./sierpinski --help (on Linux) or sierpinski.exe --help (on Windows) for more instructions. Please note that the Windows binary has only be compiled on a Linux machine using the 32-bit version of the MinGW cross-compiler. But it should work as well on Win* systems as well. Also note that by default, this sierpinski.c code prints its output to the standard output -- that can be a lot since there are lots of pyramides and triangles. So redirect it to a file or use the -o ... option. What is your smallest size-to-2^depth ratio what your printer can print nicely? ;)

description.text:
Various files that should allow you to recreate the same modification that I did.

Should be fairly self explanatory from the pics, if you have issues just hit me up. Personally I printed all parts in XT-CF20 and the bearings you need are two 8x22x7mm. Slap damper was from aliexpress https://www.aliexpress.com/item/MT09-FZ09-CNC-Steering-Damper-Stabilizer-Linear-Reversed-Safety-Control-For-Yamaha-MT-09-FZ-09/32673579412.html?spm=2114.01010208.8.3.onAydT

Use a m8 washer between the main 3d printed mount and the bottom bearing.

Forward end of slap damper mounts in one of the existing holes on the rudder base - just drill it out and tap for the screw. I also added a 1mm Nylon washer just to protect the base from the small bit of rotation that the part experiences there. If you don't use that then you'll need to make that part 1mm taller or print a spacer.

I would recommend tapping both holes on the main 3D printed part too.

Detailed creature bust printable without support.

I've been meaning to do more work with no support required for a while now. (My previous piece needed heaps of it...) Still working on another full character piece that should be printable without support as well, but started free sculpting while at Fab Lab Adelaide on the weekend and this happened. Good session. Cleaned up and reworked a bit at home and released in to the wild!

Tested on my Dremel 3D40, sliced with Simplify3D.

Should be fine printed at other sizes (smaller or larger). Please be sure to share your makes if you print him!

Low = 110,000 polys (approx)
Mid = 528,000 polys (approx)
Low = 1,573,000 polys (approx)

(Notes - Worth using a raft on this one as it basically fused to my print bed.)

description.text:
I have marked this as "work in progress" as the concept is still under test, any user printing this design please give feedback.

Looking through the options for x-axis belt clamps and tension I decided that none of the designs suited my needs, I did not want to dismantle part of the printer to add a tensioner and clip style tensioners do not offer the same level of adjustment.

So I designed my own, it both clamps the belt and then allows you to tension the belt.

Fitting Steps:
Fit belt in to one block and then attach block loosely to the carriage using appropriate length of screw.

Fit the belt in to the 2nd block ensuring that you take up as much slack on the belt as you can but not so much that you struggle to fit. Again leaving the cross screws slightly loose to allow movement.

Once blocks/belt have been fitted and you are satisfied fit the bolt between the blocks and hand tighten, I squeeze my blocks together and tightened as far as I could. (I would highly recommend that you find a guide on finding the optimum belt tension).

Once your belt is tensioned tighten the four cross screws and happy printing.

Note: Fitting the belt is a bit awkward.

Note 2: you may need to turn your x-axis limit switch to stop it catching on the tensioner block.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used 100% infill as I thought that would offer the best strength and lower infill din't offer much print time advantage.

Ante todo gracias a Ayunken por la ayuda prestada los primeros días, el artista que ha cambiado el programa y librerías para que la matriz led funcione es él, además de otras cosas.

He modificado las carcasas y piernas de Ayunkowi para que sean más resistentes.

  • He reforzado los soportes de los servos (SG90) en el cuerpo porque rompían con facilidad,
  • He hecho las piernas más cortas y resistentes.
  • He rediseñado la cabeza para que encaje el sensor de proximidad y quede fijado, así como he puesto un soporte para la tarjeta de bluetooth y la botonera. En la parte superior hay 4 soportes para la shield de arduino.

La cabeza es más alta de lo normal (7mm) para que entren 2 baterias 18650 encima de los servos para no tener que desmontar el robot al cambiar pilas.
Para cargarlo utiliza una placa de un powerbank con salida 5V 2A, desde el positivo se pasa por el interruptor para después ir a cualquier pin de 5V de la shield. El negativo a cualquier pin GND de la shield.

ELECTRÓNICA:

Arduino nano328.
Arduino nano shield.
Modulo bluetooth HC-06.
Placa de carga de powerbank (1,5€ en aliexpress).
4x servos SG90.
MAX7219 + matriz led.
2x microswitch con botón largo.
Interruptor.
Buzzer.

En el que yo usé el lado que tiene el microusb hembra es el de carga de las baterías y el que tiene el usb estándar hembra es el de descarga, tienes que soldar 2 cables en los pines de los extremos del usb grande para sacar los 5v

Antes que nada felicitarte por el trabajo.Hace un tiempo que vi el Ayunkowi original y lo estamos haciendo como proyecto educativo con mis alumnos de Tecnología Industrial de 2º Bach.
Mi idea es que se lo curren un poquito para que aprendan lo máximo, por eso estamos rediseñado todas las piezas nosotros con Freecad.
Lo tenemos bastante avanzado pero estoy un poco atascado con el tema de la alimentación.
Primero pusimos 4 pilas AA de 1,5 v conectadas al Vin del Arduino nano pero se consumen muy rápido con determinados movimientos del robot y a veces se para e incluso llega a respetarse el micro.
He visto la solución que has dado con el power bank y me parece muy interesante ya que queremos utilizar luego el robot para que aprendan a programarlo ellos...yo ya lo he estado probando y desde el lenguaje por bloques "Bitbloq" de bq se hace muy fácil...
AHI vienne mi duda !!!
podría tener alimentado a la vez el robot vía power bank y conectado por usb al pc para programarlo?
..o se generaría algún conflicto entre las alimentaciones? ya que según te he entendido conectas el power bank a " cualquier 5v de la shield"...
lo digo porque una parte del proyecto va a ser que estén programandolo.
Gracias por tu aportación!

comments.text:
Muy buenas me alegro de que funcione el Bluetooth por fin! Jjj el robot tiene 3 modos con los botones, el botón 1 (modo 1) el botón 2( modo 2) y los 2 botones a la vez (modo 3) el modo 4 es el de la App y en el momento que se vincula con la App deja de lado los otros modos. El modo 3 está deshabilitado, es un detector de sonido, no conseguí que funcionara bien.
Las conexiones de la botonera son las siguientes :
El + a cualquier pin (v) de la shield
El - a cualquier pin (g) de la shield
Y luego el 1 y el 2 a los pines de señal (s) de a4 y a5.
Uno te quedará con los 3 pines conectados y el otro solo con el de señal.
Ya casi lo tienes todo ánimo.

comments.text:
Me ha costado un poco lo del modulo, el HC-05 trae el botón de poder, debo oprimirlo? o que hago, yo he hecho lo siguiente :
1 subo el programa a la placa con el modulo desconectado
2 desconecto la placa
3 conecto el bluetooth pero no la energía
4 una vez conectada la placa conecto la energía del modulo
5 pero la luz arranca a parpadear normal, no se porque
y después miro en el celular y me aparece el bluetooth pero como HC-05 no como ZOWI, no se que estoy haciendo mal, pues incluso he tratado con el monitor serie para configurar manualmente los comandos AT y lo he puesto en 9600 pero el monitor pareciera no conectarse al modulo pues a pesar de que carga el programa pues en el monitor me lo muestra, yo no me logro comunicar con el BT podías darme un paso a paso pues algo estoy haciendo mal y no se que es.
comments.author: Enducross

comments.text:
Muy buenas, es más fácil de lo que parece, el módulo utiliza el mismo bus de comunicación serie que el usb por eso no te deja comunicarme con el por el monitor serie.
Si el modulo no ha sido manipulado, en el programa de configuración del hc 05, tienes que poner en serial. Begin 9600.
Cargas el programa con el modulo desconectado completamente, desconecta usb, conecta completamente el modulo y alimenta el arduino.
Debería funcionar.
En caso de no funcionar utiliza un módulo usb ftdi para programarlo manualmente con el monitor serie de arduino.
Un saludo.

comments.text:
Heeeey!! Está genial, y mucho más aseadito que el mío. Es cierto que las patas quedaban muy enclenques y esa reforma para que sean resistentes y el anclaje reforzado de los servos a la base es cierto que se necesitaba, yo mismo me lo cargué al atornillarlos. Y ahora ya tiene su versión con batería recargable, creo que ya tenemos el Zowi más económico posible con la misma funcionalidad que el original. Supongo que habrás usado el módulo de nivel de batería, ya que es importante para las LiPo que no se usen por debajo de un voltaje mínimo, pues se mueren si agotas toda su carga. No lo sé sólo por haberlo leído, jeje.
Lo de llamarme artista sí que no es para tanto, pero bueno, se agradece. Un video de cómo se mueve estaría tope.
Gran trabajo. Al resto animaos, aquí estamos para lo que necesitéis.

title: Belt redesign for FT5 Revision 2 (X-Y idlers)

description.text:
This is a revised and reworked version from this design
Differences :
steppermotors are fixed with 4 bolts instead of 2 and adjusting the tension of the belt is now done at the side of the pulley instead of adjusting the stepper. Pulley support is fixed with 3 M5 bolts and nuts in the 2020-profiles.
This is a lot easier to manage and one can leave the belt attached to the X-axis all the time when working in that area. Just loosen the pulley support and leave the belt attached.

Things :

  • Larger stepper support for the right side with the integrated cablechain support
  • Stepper support for the left side
  • One pulley support for left and right side

  • conical piece to be mounted under the bearings.

  • new support for the right X-pulley that fits better with the Y-endstop

20170816 - added 3mm X support

Tip : Use 3d-Tool to have a detailed look on this thing

Printer:

FT5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,4

Infill:

50

Notes:

I made them in ABS with a 0,6 nozzle ...

title: DJI Mavic Pro: Yet Another Tablet Holder (Yath)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I made the "Yet Another Tablet Holder" (in short Yath) for my Samsung SM-T710 tablet as I did not like the way it was mounted underneath the DJI Mavic Pro's RC.

The whole setup is compatible with the 1" RAM ball bases mount system.

The RAM mount double socket used is a RAM mount and is 2" long (the: RAM-B-103-A-238U)
It can be found on thingiverse, and if needed you could 3D print it.

To make Yath more universal for other tablets I also created a Velcro tablet mount. ¯\(ツ)/¯

Please fly safe!
Mavic-pro.help

Disclaimer: In addition, due to damage and accidents etc. by using this part I do not take any responsibility!

Printer:

XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

main mount 30%, holder 20%

Notes:

The above picture examples are all printed with PLA.

This is a broken brooklyn bridge.

Estas são peças para um suporte com variação de posicionamento eletrônico controlado por computador, para captura de múltiplas imagens de um objeto com variação de altura e iluminação, com a finalidade de aumentar a profundidade de foco do microscópio e determinar a estrutura tridimensional do objeto.

As principais partes estruturais do suporte, de plástico, foram modeladas com técnicas de CAD e podem ser fabricadas por qualquer impressora 3D. O suporte inclui um motor de passo controlado por um microcontrolador (Arduino) que por sua vez é controlado por um computador através de interface USB. O microscópio é movimentado na direção vertical por um parafuso acionado pelo motor.

description.text: I took the design and increased the internal hole size tso it can take 1.75 and 3mm filament (ID should be 3.2mm). I also extended it so it could pass through the top of an Ikea Lack table (the 6mm tube is 5.3cm long). My plan is to use this directly above the middle of the X-axis. I tried the original filter with some tubing last night but the filament was sticking on the walls of the tube. I also thought the hole was a little on the snug side. Thanks to Jhedstrom for the original design.

description.text:
This is a Y pipe connector, size M20/27.
The pitch is 14G (aka 1/14in = 0,071in = 1,81mm)
The tube thickness is 3mm

As water may leak from between the layers, I dipped it into hot paraffin. Once dried (<2mins), it's waterproof.
Don't dip it into hot paraffin if you used PLA, it'll shrink the part and threads won't work anymore

It's compatible with M20/27 connectors for gardening tools (like Gardena) and washing-machine water pipes.

To resist water, UV, mud and kids, it's printed in PETG.

author: fritztoch

title: Anet A6 Mainboard Cover with 80 mm Fan

description.text:
C'est ma première contribution pour imprimantes Anet A6.
La carte mère de l'Anet a besoin de refroidissement suplementaire vu les faibles dissipateurs .

J'ai conçu ce support équipé d'un ventilateur de 80 mm pour refroidir la carte mère, et en particulier les dissipateurs thermiques.
Tous les câbles et connecteurs sont accessibles sans avoir à retirer le couvercle.

Le support vient simplement se clipser sur la carte mère cela n'est pas extremement ferme mais vu le faible poid du ventilateur
cela suffit amplement, et surtout permet d'etre retirer très facilement.

Les trous des vis pour le ventilo sont imprimés en 6 mm de diamètre.
Vous pourriez avoir besoin de repercer si vos vis sont trop juste, cela dépend aussi de la tolérance de votre imprimante.

J'ai utiliser 2 ventilateurs "ENERMAX T.B.SILENCE - UCTB8 de 80mm 1600 RPM (1 pour l'alim et l'autre pour la carte mère)
Ils sont branchés sur l'alimentation (voir photos)

Merci de poster une photo si vous avez imprimer le support.

Merci.

English

This is my first contribution to Anet A6 printers.
The motherboard of the Anet needs additional cooling considering the low heat sinks.

I designed this bracket equipped with an 80 mm fan to cool the motherboard, and especially the heat sinks.
All cables and connectors are accessible without removing the cover.

The support simply comes to clip on the motherboard it is not extremely firm but given the low weight of the fan
This is enough ample, and especially allows to be removed very easily.

The screw holes for the fan are printed in 6 mm diameter.
You may need to drill down if your screws are too fair, it also depends on the tolerance of your printer.

I have to use 2 fans "ENERMAX T.B.SILENCE - UCTB8 of 80mm 1600 RPM (1 for the power supply and the other for the motherboard)
They are plugged into the power supply (see pictures)

Please post a photo if you have to print the media.

Thank you.

Print without support (it already has built in support where needed), 5% to 10% infill will give you nicer top surfaces.

The mouth requires some post processing work with a knife to get right, if I have the time I'll redo the lower part of the head to fix this.

Both the guide tube and the spool holder fit in the back side of the printer in between the gap of the original filament tray, allowing the door to still shut completely. The best alignment of the two pieces that I have found is to spread them both out as far apart as possible.

This is a concealed fixing wall hanger.

Simply screw the bracket to the wall using a small counter sunk screw .The base has to go the right way up - there is a recess in the square cutout on the top side.

Insert the hook into the hole angled down slightly as in the diagram, and press down until there is a click.

I Printed at 45% infill with 3 perimeters and 3 top and bottom layers in PLA.
the higher the infill the stronger it should be ,but i haven't tried it yet to see if the hook will
still fit. The tolerances are quite tight.

I've tested the hook with a heavy leather jacket and no problems, I would recommend using it for something smaller though

I will add different shape bases when I get a chance.

sorry I have to add this -

disclaimer : If you print this you do so at your own risk. if anything breaks either with the hook or bracket or anything you hang on it, I will not be held responsible.

title: Multi-purpose desk clamp/stalk - add your own fixture!

description.text:
I needed a way to mount my GoPro camera in front of my printer for purposes of timelapse photography during prints, so to Solidworks I went to design a clamp for my desk.

I had a GoPro mount STL lying around and figured if I could just union it to the top of the clamp's STL in Autodesk Netfabb then that should work, and it turned out great.

It then occurred to me that the same process could be applied to pretty much anything, so I decided to upload the unmodified clamp base for other users who might have another application in mind. Webcam mounts, phone holders, cable tidiers; surely better on top of a clamp that some guy posted one day to Thingiverse (disclaimer: results may vary).

Printing guidelines

The piece in the photos was printed in lime green ABS at 235/80 with a 0.6mm nozzle, brim and 0.21875mm layer heights, but a standard 0.4 will work just fine.

Note - don't print as shown in the STL previews, parts will require rotating to print properly.

The clamp bracket will likely be stronger if printed on its side instead with regard to loading/layer orientation, though, as long as care is taken to make sure the internal thread is printing properly.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sPaOJwpgPAA

Monoprice Select Mini

Yes

author: Casowsky

description.text:
This is a bedside light that is crafted in the style of a futuristic shopping centre as seen on The Jetsons.
Includes an assortment of Jetsons cars.

This model was printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 in PLA.
No supports are necessary.
I scaled the parts up by %400 to make the model you see in the pictures.
I used 2 bright yellow 3mm LEDs on the inside of the windows (which are hollow) and are wired through one of the necks into the base where the rest of the electronics lie (batteries, switch, and resistors).
You'll need to figure out the circuit yourself based on the type of LEDs you are using.
One thing that really helps the lighting is to glue some aluminum foil to the underside of the ceiling so it reflects the light back and makes it diffuse more into the windows.
Print the windows in translucent PLA for the best effect.
The pieces need to be glued (no snap fits, sorry).
There are tabs on the shop windows to help align the floors properly.
Hopefully the file names are self-explanatory so the assembly should be straight forward.
I used a plastic project box for the base and electronics housing.

Unfortunately it may not fit quarters, but it can be fixed - either by editing the thing itself or by opening the cover and placing the quarters inside the money bank!
This students started learning Tinkercad through ProjectIgnite just a few weeks ago and he made a huge progress!
I printed it using PLA and it took us about 6 hours to print both the box and the cover. But the result was pretty good.

This is a new X carriage for the Hypercube, designed to hold the E3D Titan extruder.

The carriage has been designed with the objective of getting a heavy duty and reliable platform for a continuous production 3D printer. Features are:

  • Solid holder for the E3D Titan extruder, direct drive, and room for the hotend fan.
  • Uses LM10LUU (long) bearings and 10mm smooth rod for the X axis, for increased stiffness, specially in printers with a long X axis. You can use the default Hypercube XY joiner files, since they are already prepared for 10mm rod, but you need to use steel, solid rod.
  • Cable chain holder for 10mm chains.
  • One piece design, apart from belt and bearing clamps.
  • Every nut is enclosed.
  • X endstop, just like in the original carriage.
  • Individual belt tensioners, just like in the original design.

You need to print:

  • 1x titan carriage
  • 2x LM10LUU clamp
  • 1x belt clamp

More info, updates and mods can be found in my Hypercube repository: https://github.com/diegotrap/hypercube

description.text:
When using CNC soon or later you'll find the need of the touch probe - a device which detects any movement in any direction on the top of the styli. It can be used to detect the edges of the stock, to find the centre of the hole, the top surface of the stock (Z probe), etc.

Renishaw touch probes are considered as the best on the market and they can cost 1K-2K Pounds.

http://www.renishaw.com/en/new-ultra-compact-inspection-touch-probes-for-lathes-and-turning-centres--12389

When having 3D printer and some mechanical skills we could build poor man touch probe for less than 20 Pounds. Here is my first design to explore the mechanical challenges of the touch probe. There are many touch probe designs in the net, this particular design is optimised for CNC milling, ideally all parts should be milled to get better accuracy and rigidity.

The prototype is working well - after 3D printing the components (0.1mm layers 50%) and assembling the unit the sensitivity is excellent.

More text will be added soon.....

We can make the styli from some screw or do it on lathe but it's worth to buy a good quality styli with ruby tip. I found this good supplier:

http://www.itp-probes.com/OnlineShop.aspx?ID=itp_OnlineShop&dn=0&pn=552&sc=2152263875

In the design was used the model TH M3 030 04 031

I found some weak points in this particular design:

  • I used 6mm balls and 6x12 rolls from bearings. I found that as smaller is diameter than lower are the forces to get reliable galvanic contact. On 6mm balls/rolls the spring should be about 3x-5x stronger than the ball point pen spring. With smaller diameter the spring could be softer. Ideally the diameter of the ball/rolls should be 3.5 .. 4.0mm

  • Ideally the spring should be conical type spring - wide on top and narrow on where touching the movable plate.

  • There is one important thing in the current design - if parts were made from rigid material (milled from aluminium and hard plastics) extreme precision is required. Small misalignments of the balls / cylinders will result in tendency of the probe to stay in open state (no contact).

The balls and the cylinders are from bearings - they are precise, hardened and polished. I found that with the time the resistance of the contact increases maybe because of oxidation and corrosion (a drop of oil may prevent the oxidation). So I would strongly recommend to use stainless steel balls and cylinders if possible - this is the heart of the whole design and we should pay more attention to it.

The balls and the cylinders could be glued with drop of epoxy on the bottom of the channels.

The electrical contacts between balls were made with M2.5 screws and wires. If the moving part is 3D printed or milled from plastic (cylinders are insulated from GND) all balls could be connected in serial. If any ball loses contact to the cylinder the current loop is broken and the resistance increases. Ideally 2 - 5mA current should flow through the balls.

If the moving part is milled from aluminium (cylinders connected to GND) then each ball should get individual wire to the electronic board. Detecting if a single ball was disconnected could be done in many different ways - one possibility is to use resistor bridge and comparator as shown on the schematic below.

BTW I found one quite interesting project - it's called Penny probe (they use 1p coin as sensor plate):

http://www.brusselsprout.org/cnc/1p-probe/

The idea of Penny probe is ingenious: "... Rather than 6 ball bearings, how about just 3? By it’s very nature this would be inherently stable" - not surprisingly the Penny probe shows supreme precision and reliability.

Of course there is never "free lunch" - the Penny probe is working well in vertical direction but not very reliable in horizontal direction (we can't guarantee that the central shaft is always resting in the same position).
